journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Innovative approach to air management strategy for turbocharged diesel aircraft engines

article-meta.aff: Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, University of Ljubljana, Ljubljana, Slovenia

author-notes.corresp: Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, University of Ljubljana, Aškerčeva 6, SI-1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia. email: tomaz.katrasnik@fs.uni-lj.si

abstract.p: Theoretical study on performance optimization of a turbocharged diesel aircraft engine is presented in this article. It is based on a verified engine thermodynamics and fluid dynamics simulation model. An efficient air management strategy for increasing power-to-engine displacement ratios of a turbocharged diesel aircraft engines is introduced and analysed. Air management strategies generally applied to turbocharged spark ignition aircraft engines do not enable to take full advantage of potentials given by turbocharging diesel aircraft engines. A conceptually different air management strategy, where turbocharger's waste-gate is fully closed up to the critical altitude, was therefore proposed and investigated in this article. Proposed air management strategy assures increased safety of engine operation through very simple and reliable engine controlling. Guidelines for selecting adequate air management components are also given in this article.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Reduction of operating costs has become one of the major objectives in general aviation. Reduction of fuel consumption and fuel costs are the most promising ways to achieve this goal. Both objectives can be accomplished by application of the diesel engines, since it is well known that diesel engines are the most efficient energy converters of fossil fuels for vehicle propulsion [1]. Besides their higher efficiency, diesel engines are able to consume wider spectrum offuels than spark ignition engines that are widely applied in the general aviation. Spark ignition engine applied in general aviation widely run on 100 LL fuel, while some of them are allowed to run also on RON 95 or AKI 91 fuel, e.g. reference [2]. Wider spectrum of fuels that can be applied in diesel engines, i.e. kerosene-based fuels or other heavy fuels, thus results also in improved fuel availability and, if 100 LL fuel is considered, also in notably reduced fuel costs.

Besides the above-mentioned advantages, application of diesel engines in aircrafts features numerous additional advantages. Diesel engine-powered aircrafts have longer operating range due to lower fuel consumption. Kerosene-based fuels or other heavy fuels feature lower inflammability than commonly used gasoline fuels, whereas compared to 100 LL diesel fuels are also lead free. Inherently, diesel engines are generally more durable than spark ignition engines, since heavy fuels provide better lubrication, whereas lower maximum in-cylinder temperature and lower exhaust gas temperature result in lower thermal loadings. The later fact originates from the nature of the diesel cycle engines that operate at air–fuel ratios larger than stoichiometric. Diesel engines generally feature longer time between overhauls, resulting in additional reduction of the operating costs. They also feature lower electromagnetic noise emission due to the absence of an ignition system that reduces interference with navigation and communication systems.

Lower power-to-weight ratio (PtWR) and lower power-to-engine displacement ratio (PtVR = P/(NcVc)) of diesel engines compared to adequate spark ignition engines have been among the main arguments against wider application of diesel aircraft engines in the past. However, due to recent advances in the field of high-speed direct injection diesel engines, presently, diesel aircraft engines feature comparable or even higher PtVRs and thus also PtWRs than spark ignition aircraft engines by retaining all advantages of diesel engines, thus making diesel engines very attractive also for aircraft applications. Modern spark ignition-turbocharged aircraft engines typically feature PtWR in the range from approximately 0.8 to approximately 1.25 kW/kg [3–6], whereas it is possible to attain these values with the liquid-cooled diesel engines as reported in this article or even exceed them with the air-cooled diesel engines [7].

One of the major issues in achieving high PtVRs that results in high PtWRs is determination of adequate air management strategy for diesel aircraft engines, since trapped mass of fresh air in the cylinders directly restricts maximum brake mean effective pressure (BMEP) of the particular engine design. This article thus introduces and analyses the air management strategy for turbocharged diesel aircraft engines which is based on a feasibility study of adapting a multi-purpose turbocharged four-stroke liquid-cooled diesel engine for the aircraft applications. The main objectives are to attain specified power outputs at specified operating conditions as well as to attain these parameters with a simple and reliable air supply configuration to enable safe and low-maintenance operation and to comply with certification requirements.

sec.title: 2 REQUIREMENT SPECIFICATION
sec.p: The main development objective was to comply with the requirements specified by the aircraft engine manufacturer in terms of the engine power output characteristic at different altitudes and the engine maximum weight while simultaneously maximizing fuel economy. Besides all, utilized technologies should comply with certification regulations.

The engine maximum dry weight should not exceed 250 kg including all heat exchangers and engine's accessories. This weight limit is imposed based on the structural limitations of the aircraft and its manoeuvrability. Engine power outputs at selected engine speeds and altitudes were defined considering aircraft and propeller characteristics and anticipated aircraft utilization. The engine should develop the following power outputs at specified altitudes: (a) take-off power 184 kW (250 HP) at 3800–4200 r/min at the sea level with possibility of attaining 199 kW (270 HP) at 4200 r/min for a limited period of time, (b) continuous power 154 kW (210 HP) at 3400–3700 r/min at 3000 m, and (3) continuous power 93 kW (126 HP) at 3400–3700 r/min at 6000 m. High power output at the sea level compared to the power output at high altitude is particularly preferable, since increased take-off power significantly shortens the required runway length and improves initial climbing ability of the aircraft. Continuous power outputs at 3000 and 6000 were specified at lower engine speed than the engine speed corresponding to the take-off power output to ensure low brake-specific fuel consumption of the engine and increased engine durability.

It was also claimed in the requirement specification that engine should be equipped with a single-stage fixed geometry exhaust-driven turbocharger to comply with the fuel economy objective, to comply with the certification regulations, and to ensure low manufacturing costs of the engine as well as its safety and reliability.

sec.title: 3 DESCRIPTION OF THE ENGINE
sec.p:
Due to the primary objective to achieve superior fuel economy, it was decided to utilize a diesel engine. Moreover, due to the same objective, it was decided to utilize a diesel engine featuring a relatively small swept volume to ensure high mechanical efficiency of the engine. Since diesel engines with high BMEP are not commonly applied in aircrafts, an innovative air management strategy was developed to comply with the requirement specifications. Resulting from the above objectives, a six-cylinder in-line 3.2 -L four-stroke high-speed direct injection turbocharged diesel engine was selected as a suitable power plant. General engine data are summarized in Table 1. Table 1
Basic engine data
Engine type Diesel, four-stroke, monoblock, watercooled, turbocharged, intercooled
Number of cylinders 6, in-line
Bore (mm) 85
Stroke (mm) 94
Compression ratio 17:1
Number of valves 2
Injection system Unit-injectors

Analysed diesel engine is equipped with unit-injectors that enable attaining high engine performance and simultaneously significantly contribute to the safety of the engine operation, since unit-injectors, unlike common-rail, ensure safe operation of the engine also during cutouts of the electric circuit or during eventual failure of separate unit injectors. Liquid-cooling, although imposing a weight penalty against air-cooled engines, reduces thermal loading of the components. As a result, it positively influences engine reliability and durability, while simultaneously enabling high specific power output of the engine and thus high mechanical efficiency. It also enables operation of the engine at maximum power output for longer periods. Monoblock design of the engine makes possible attaining high PtWRs and high PtVRs through high maximum in-cylinder pressures (analysed engine can be continuously operated at maximum in-cylinder pressure 16 MPa). Moreover, low thermal loading of the engine head is achieved due to very good cooling capability of monoblock design. Four-stroke design additionally reduces thermal loadings of the engine compared to the two-stroke design enhancing reliability and durability of the engine and improves its fuel economy, although it clearly features a weight penalty.

It was decided that experimental and simulation analyses of the aircraft engine are performed using diesel fuel D2. According to the results presented in reference [8], it is possible to match the performance of the engine with a D2 fuel to that of a JP-8 fuel by engine calibration. Moreover, according to reference [8], brake-specific fuel consumption (BSFC) values of both fuels are very close when the performance is matched. It can therefore be concluded that results for diesel fuel D2 is representative for kerosene-based fuels and other heavy fuels. It should also be noted that the analysed engine has already successfully undergone endurance tests with Jet A fuel.

Utilization of an exhaust-driven turbocharger is definitively preferable over utilization of mechanically driven supercharger if fuel economy is one of the major objectives. It is also reasonable to use a single single-stage turbocharger, since maximum design altitude is 6000 m. Single-stage turbocharging is favourable also due to the low system complexity, low weight, and low cost, whereas it makes possible attaining adequate performance up to maximum design attitude of 6000 m (or higher if required). Similar approach is pursued also by other engines designs, whereas specific multi-stage turbocharging systems also apply only single turbocharging stage up to maximum design altitude defined in this project [9]. Variable geometry turbines and/or compressors were disallowed due to safety and reliability reasons. Very high BMEP and PtVRs (BMEP up to 1.8 MPa and PtVR up to 62 kW/dm3 or 84 HP/dm3 at the sea level) indicate that the use of waste-gate has to be limited or preferably even eliminated within the operating range of engine that is specified in section 2 to enable sufficient boost pressure and thus sufficiently high pressure ratios across the compressor. Preferably, waste-gate should thus only be utilized as a safety device preventing over-speeding of the turbocharger during off-design engine operation, whereas, if possible, it should not be used to control air supply during normal engine operation. Elimination of the waste-gate from the air management control strategy of the aircraft engine in projected engine operating range is a demanding task from the engine air breathing components point of view, since thereby air flow is characterized only by characteristics of compressor, turbine, intercooler, ambient conditions, and engine power output. At certain engine speed, cyclic fuel delivery is set to control engine power output, while maximum fuelling is limited based on the flight altitude to ensure safe engine operation, e.g. limited minimum air/fuel ratio and limited turbocharger speed.

Utilization of the waste-gate only as a safety device enables very simple and reliable engine controlling and assures increased safety of the engine operation. Actuation of the waste-gate by means of the diaphragm cell that comprises a membrane is problematic for aircraft engine applications according to the experience of the customer, whereas this deficiency is addressed also by other researchers [10], since waste-gate control system failure is hazardous. Combination of hydraulically and mechanically actuated control systems is therefore widely used in aircraft applications; however, these systems are relatively expensive and increase engine weight [10].

Analysing the engine components with the aim to comply with the requirement specifications, it was concluded that most of the original engine components could also be used for its aircraft version with the major exception of the dry sump lubrication system. Reconstruction of the intake and the exhaust manifold was also performed due to packaging constraints and improved manifold dynamics in the engine speed range commonly utilized in the aircrafts as will be shown in the section 4. Moreover, redesigning the manifolds provided an opportunity to reduce engine weight. The newly developed intake manifold in welded thin wall aluminium and the exhaust manifold in welded thin wall stainless steel made possible fulfilment of the requirement on the engine maximum weight. Projected engine weight thus amounts to 248 kg including all heat exchangers and engine's accessories. This results in PtWR up to 0.80 kW/kg (1.09 HP/kg or equivalently PtWR−1 = 0.92 kg/HP) at the sea level.

It is discernable from the above data that investigated engine should feature a very high PtVR and superior BMEP in the field of aircraft engines. Both values are directly linked to a very efficient air management strategy. On the other hand, the developed engine would not feature top PtWR, since this parameter is primarily linked to the engine construction, whereas it is to a lesser extent related to the air management strategy. Although the engine features high PtWR in the range of liquid cooled four-stroke diesel engines, it ranges in the lower end of PtWRs of modern spark ignition-turbocharged aircraft engines [3–6]. However, if long operating range of the aircraft is desired, the take-off weight of the aircraft with the analysed engine is comparable to the take-off weight of the aircrafts with the highest PtWR spark ignition-turbocharged aircraft engines and the same maximum engine power, since additional weight of the engine is compensated by the smaller fuel weight at the same operating range, as discussed in subsection 6.1. Altogether, the above features are in line with the customer demands, since high fuel economy, high reliability, high durability, and high continuous power output are among top priorities of the investigated engine.

sec.title: 4 SIMULATION MODEL
sec.p: Air management strategies were analysed by the first author's engine thermodynamics and fluid mechanics simulation tool. The simulation toll is described in details in reference [11], whereas only brief description is outlined here. The simulation tool is based on zero-dimensional, one-dimensional, and quasi-dimensional methods and is capable of simulating steady-state and transient operation of an arbitrary engine configuration, including variety of different turbocharged engines. Engine manifolds and their boundaries are simulated using one-dimensional techniques. Interior of the pipes is simulated with finite volume schemes and extended equations of the method of characteristics suitable of dealing with variable gas properties are used to represent the boundaries. Framework for simulating single-entry turbine and compressor considering variable gas properties is outlined in reference [12], whereas framework for simulating twin-entry turbine considering variable gas properties is outlined in reference [13]. Extended boundary equations capable of considering variable gas properties for simulating opened and closed ends, and flow through the cylinder were derived from the equations proposed by Benson [14] in a similar way as described in references [12, 13]. Pipe junctions are calculated using pressure loss model [15], whereas intercooler is simulated with the model proposed by Pearson et al. [16]; all applied models were extended in order to consider variable gas properties and their composition. Engine cylinders and other control volumes are simulated using zero-dimensional methods, whereas it is possible to choose between zero- and quasi-dimensional combustion models. Rate-of-heat-release curves applied in the simulation model were derived from the measured in-cylinder pressure traces. Friction mean effective pressure data used in the simulation model were also obtained by experiments preformed on the baseline engine.

It is well known that representing compressor and turbine characteristic by non-dimensional groups of parameters enables unique representation of turbomachinery performance, independent of the inlet conditions, e.g. altitude, Mach number, Reynolds number effects, and thus ambient pressure and temperature [17, 18]. The non-dimensional parameters are determined according to the Buckingham Pi theorem, e.g. reference [18]. It is common practice to omit diameter and gas constant from the dimensionless parameters, yielding m·T/p, nTC/T, and PR –pressure ratio as parameters for representing turbomachinery performance [17, 18]. Such representation of turbomachinery performance is incorporated in the simulation model and it thus represents a suitable tool for modelling engine performance for variable ambient conditions.

The simulation tool has been previously applied and verified in many R&D projects. For the purpose of this analysis, experiments were conducted at the sea level and simulation model was calibrated to ensure very good agreement of the simulation and experimental data. Figure 1 shows comparison of simulation and experimental full load data of the baseline engine over the speed range. Results are compared based on the equal injected fuel quantity, which was measured with uncertainty less than 0.2 per cent in the analysed flow range. Air mass flow was measured with the laminar air flow meter featuring uncertainty less than 0.9 per cent in the analysed flow range, temperature was measured with the K-type thermocouples featuring uncertainty less than 0.4 per cent in the analysed temperature range, uncertainty of pressure measurement including signal processing was less than 0.8 per cent and torque was measured with uncertainty less than 0.5 per cent. Based on a very good agreement of experimental and simulation data and based on adequate models of turbomachinery performance, it can be concluded that the applied simulation model represents a suitable tool to analyse air management strategies of a turbocharged aircraft diesel engine. Fig. 1
Comparison of simulation and experimental engine parameters – engine power output, boost pressure, air mass flow through the compressor, exhaust gas temperature, exhaust gas pressure, and relative air/fuel ratio

As addressed in section 3, intake and exhaust manifold were subjected to reconstruction due to packaging constraints. Thereby geometry of the manifolds was also optimized with regard to engine performance in the speed range corresponding to the continuous power output of the engine. Figure 2 shows variation of the volumetric efficiency (ηv) as function of primary pipe length at 3400 r/min; methods for optimizing ηv are thoroughly revised in reference [19]. Fig. 2
Variation of volumetric efficiency over the primary pipe length

sec.title: 5.1 Requirements on air management components
sec.p:
From the specifications provided in section 2, it is discernable that PtVRs up to 62 kW/dm3 are to be attained if required power outputs should be realized by the engine featuring 3.2 dm3 swept volume. Moreover, considering the specifications in section 2, it can be evaluated that maximum BMEP exceeds 1.8 MPa (Table 2) as given by (1) where P is engine power, ne engine speed, Vc swept volume of a single cylinder, Nc number of cylinders, and Nst = 2 for four-stroke engines. Both maximum PtVR and maximum BMEP indicate very high or superior values in the field of aircraft engines. Table 2
Parameters of the turbocharged diesel aircraft engine
Altitude (m) 0 0 0 3000 3000 6000 6000
ne (r/min) 4200 4200 3800 3700 3400 3700 3400
P (kW) 199 184 184 154 154 93 93
m·C,corr (kgK/(s×MPa)) 50.6 48.5 42.7 50.6 45.4 54.9 49.2
PRC (–) 3.45 3.26 2.99 3.6 3.38 3.78 3.55
nTC,corr (r/s/K) 124.2 120 113.2 126.9 121.5 131.3 125.6
m·C (kg/s) 0.302 0.289 0.255 0.216 0.194 0.164 0.147
pa,C (kPa) 333 316 293 244 231 174 164
nTC (r/s) 2108 2037 1922 2080 1992 2073 1983
nTC@288 K (r/s) 2108 2037 1922 2153 2063 2228 2131
ρIM/ρatm (–) 2.74 2.63 2.48 2.9 2.77 3.04 2.89
BSFC (g/(kW × h)) 252 250 229 234 224 260 246
λ (–) 1.45 1.52 1.45 1.43 1.34 1.63 1.54
pc,max (MPa) 14.8 13.8 14.1 11.6 12.2 7.6 7.6
BMEP (MPa) 1.78 1.64 1.82 1.56 1.7 0.94 1.03
PtVR (kW/dm3) 62.2 57.5 57.5 48.1 48.1 29.1 29.1
PtWR (kW/kg) 0.80 0.74 0.74 0.62 0.62 0.38 0.38

Analysing factors influencing power output of the engine without exhaust gas recirculation (2) it can be concluded that after selecting the engine together with the fuel type and its operating speed range, it is possible to influence power output only by its effective efficiency (ηeff), minimum value of relative air–fuel ratio (λset), volumetric efficiency (ηv), and density in the intake manifold (ρIM). QLHV denotes lower heating value of the fuel and (A/F)st stoichiometric air/fuel ratio. Effective efficiency is generally influenced by the engine design and to a minor extent by the utilized materials and manufacturing techniques, while for particular engine design it can mostly be influenced by the fuel injection equipment and its control as well as by mechanical efficiency through increased BMEP. A compromise considering maximum in-cylinder pressure should be found between the start of injection (SOI), the compression ratio, and the BMEP. In the analysed case, minimum value of relative air–fuel ratio was limited by the temperature of exhaust gasses through material properties of the exhaust manifold and of the turbine and by the soot emissions (Figs 1 and 3). Although, there is no exact minimum value of λset, it was aimed that λset is larger than 1.3 at 3400 r/min mainly to limit soot emission at approximately Bosch smoke unit 3.5 and that λset is larger than 1.4 at 4200 r/min to limit the exhaust gas temperature below 980 K. Volumetric efficiency of the analysed engine was optimized at engine speed 3400 r/min to enable favourable fuel economy at cruising conditions, as shown in Fig. 2. Although, addressed parameters poses the potential to increase engine power, their influence is much less significant than the influence of the density in the intake manifold. Fig. 3
Exhaust gas opacity for different engine speeds as a function of relative air/fuel ratio

Therefore, relative increase of the density in the intake manifold (ρIM) over the density in the standard atmosphere (ρatm) is the main focus of this study. Figure 4 shows the variation of pressure, temperature, and density of the standard atmosphere in the operating altitude range of the investigated aircraft engine. It is obvious that pressure decreases at much larger rate than temperature resulting in severe density drop with increasing altitude. Considering the above facts, it can be concluded that ρIM/ρatm should be equal or larger than approximately 2.5 at all altitudes to achieve the specified power outputs (see also Table 2). This very high increase in density could be achieved by turbocharging and subsequent charge cooling, i.e. intercooling. Considering efficiencies [20] (3) and pressure drops (4) of commonly used air-to-air intercoolers, it can be derived that compressor pressure ratio, i.e. PRC=pa,C/pb,C, should be equal or larger than 3 to achieve the specified power outputs (see also Table 2). In the above equations, ηINTC denotes efficiency of the intercooler, Tb,INTC and Ta,INTC temperature of medium before and after the intercooler, respectively, TCM temperature of the cooling medium, pa,C and Ta,C pressure and temperature after the compressor, respectively being very close to the pressure and temperature at the intercooler entry, ΔpINTC pressure drop through the intercooler, and RIM gas constant in the intake manifold. Mass flow of air and compressor pressure ratio thus determine the characteristics of an adequate compressor, whereas additionally power balance of the turbocharger determines characteristics of an adequate turbine [17, 21] (5) where ηTC is the efficiency of the turbocharger including efficiency of the turbine, compressor, and mechanical efficiency of the turbocharger, m·C and m·T mass flow through the compressor and the turbine, respectively, cp,C and cp,T specific heat at constant pressure, κC and κT ratio of specific heats and Tb,C and Tb,T temperature of the medium entering compressor and turbine, respectively, and pb,T and pa,T pressure before and after the turbine. Fig. 4
Parameters of the standard atmosphere for the analysed altitude range

sec.title: 5.2 Boost pressure control
sec.p:
The majority of air management strategies for piston aircraft engines refer to the spark ignition engines, e.g. references [22–24], since this engine type is widely applied in the general aviation. Basic ideas of air management strategies of turbocharged spark ignition aircraft engines equipped with single-stage waste-gated turbocharger are schematically depicted in Fig. 5. It can be seen in Fig. 5(a) that maximum boost pressure is kept constant from the sea level up to the critical altitude. Turbocharging is thus used to compensate for decrease in atmospheric pressure. Maximum boost pressure is controlled by the extent of the waste-gate valve opening (Fig. 5(b)) that influences m·T/m·C and thus PRC (Fig. 5(c)), as depicted in equation (5). It is obvious that TC speed increases from the sea level up to the critical altitude, as shown in Fig. 5(d). Fig. 5
Air management strategy of turbocharged spark ignition aircraft engines

The trend of the curves above the critical altitude is determined by the value of ηTC, equation (5). Generally, if ηTC does not reduce significantly with increasing altitude, the turbocharger speed would increase with increasing altitude, as depicted and analysed in references [22, 23], and it is thus necessary to open waste-gate to prevent turbocharger from overspeeding at altitudes above the critical altitude. This case is denoted by ηTC > in Fig. 5. Another, rather infrequent case, mimicked in reference [24], corresponds to decrease of the turbocharger speed with increasing altitude despite the closed waste-gate due to significantly reduced ηTC at altitudes above the critical altitude. This case is denoted by ηTC < in Fig. 5. It is therefore possible to occupy the area between ηTC > and ηTC < curves depending of the value of ηTC. It should be noted that due to illustrative nature of the Fig. 5, it was assumed that critical altitude coincides with altitude corresponding to maximum turbocharger speed under full load conditions. However, after reaching the critical altitude and thus fully closing the waste-gate, turbocharger speed does not always reach its maximum value and waste-gate could therefore remain closed in the range from the critical altitude up to the altitude corresponding to maximum turbocharger speed under full load conditions even for the case ηTC >.

Analysing the performance of production-turbocharged spark ignition engines used in general aviation, it is observed that BMEPs at maximum power are below 1.4 MPa [3–5]; engine [3] PtWR = 0.9 kW/kg and PtVR = 26.2 kW/dm3 at 2575 r/min, engine [4] PtWR = 0.98 kW/kg and PtVR = 29.1 kW/dm3 at 2500 r/min, and engine [5] PtWR = 1.24 kW/kg and PtVR = 69.9 kW/dm3 at 5800 r/min. Considering furthermore, the fact that spark ignition engines, unlike the diesel ones, need not to be operated with lean mixtures, it can be concluded that ρIM/ρatm values below 1.5 are sufficient to achieve these BMEP values (equations (1) and (2)). Therefore, moderate boost pressures are required to achieve these BMEP values resulting in PRC below 2 at the sea level. Such turbocharging strategy is inherent to spark ignition engines due to two facts. First, spark ignition engines are subjected to knock thus limiting maximum compression temperature and pressure. Second, lower in-cylinder pressures compared to the diesel engines are inherent due to design restrictions of the engines, particularly due to mechanical and thermal stresses.

It can therefore be concluded that air management strategies of turbocharged spark ignition aircraft engines do not take full advantage of turbocharging at altitudes below the critical altitude due to opening of the waste-gate. Opening of the waste-gate to prevent knock onset, therefore, significantly deteriorates potential maximum power output of the engine (equation (2)) and it also increases BSFC of the engine through pumping losses (equation (5)). Analysing characteristics of specific turbocharged diesel aircraft engines currently in the production, it can be concluded that most of them apply similar control strategies as turbocharged spark ignition aircraft engines and thus do not take full advantage of turbocharging at low altitudes.

It could additionally be concluded that application of air management strategies developed for turbocharged diesel automotive engines do also not enable to take full advantage of turbocharging the diesel aircraft engines. Automotive engines have to develop high torque at low engine speeds to ensure good drivability of the automobile. Turbocharging components that are optimized for high-torque output rather than for high-power output would tend to over-speed at high altitudes and would thus restrict the power output of the aircraft engine.

A conceptually different approach can be pursued when developing air management strategies for turbocharged diesel aircraft engines. Diesel engines are not subjected to knock and it is therefore not necessary to reduce boost pressure and waste exhaust gas enthalpy by opening of the waste-gate in a manner characteristic for spark ignition engines below the critical altitude. Below the critical altitude, boost pressure of the turbocharged diesel engine can therefore be increased significantly beyond that of the turbocharged spark ignition engines as schematically depicted by the shaded area in Fig. 6(a). This is achieved by operating the engine with closed waste-gate up to the altitude corresponding to the maximum turbocharger speed (Fig. 6(b)) ensuring maximum value of m·T/m·C throughout the whole altitude range, which results in high value of PRC (Fig. 6(c)), as depicted in equation (5). It is therefore obvious that turbocharged diesel aircraft engines could develop very high BMEP (equation (1)) and thus high PtVR and P (equation (2)) at low altitudes. This is also in line with required specifications resulting in improved initial climbing ability of the aircraft and shorter runway length. Moreover, large values of m·T/m·C ensure besides high boost pressure also high ratio between the boost and the exhaust pressure thereby reducing pumping work and improving cylinder scavenging (equation (5)). However, unlike approximately constant boost pressure value up to the critical altitude that is characteristic for turbocharged spark ignition engines (Fig. 6(a)), boost pressure decreases towards the critical altitude when applying the proposed air management strategy for turbocharged diesel aircraft engines (Fig. 6(a)). Therefore, engine power decreases with increased altitude if air–fuel ratio is maintained at approximately constant value as presented in Table 2. Fig. 6
Difference between innovative air management strategy for turbocharged diesel aircraft engines and air management strategy for turbocharged spark ignition aircraft engines

It should be noted that due to illustrative nature of the Fig. 6, it was assumed that altitude corresponding to maximum turbocharger speed and boost pressure corresponding to maximum turbocharger speed coincide for both engine types. It should also be noted that for particular diesel engine–turbocharger combinations, a need for opening the waste-gate at high altitudes exists; however, it is often possible to match engine and turbocharger in a way that maximum operating altitude of the engine is attained before maximum turbocharger speed is reached. If this is the case, it is possible to keep the waste-gate closed in the whole operating altitude range of the engine as analysed below. Maximum permissible mechanical stresses of particular engine represent the main limit for the maximum value of the boost pressure, whereas it is also necessary to consider thermal loadings of the engine and engine emissions. It could be concluded that conceptually different waste-gate control strategies that could be applied to turbocharged diesel engines (Fig. 6(b)) enable to take full advantage of turbocharged diesel aircraft engines and thus attaining very high values of BMEP and PtVR, as shown in section 6.

sec.title: 5.3 Selection of air management components
sec.p: In order to get the most out of turbocharged diesel aircraft engines, it is necessary to carefully select and match the compressor, the turbine, and the intercooler. It is very important to analyse the limiting factor(s) of air management components that restrict power output at high altitudes. This is crucial for development of devices ensuring safety of the engine operation. Considering the turbocharger, it is necessary to analyse if surge or choke limit of the compressor or maximum turbocharger speed are the limiting factors. It is very unlikely that compressor choking will limit high-altitude power output if turbocharger is adequately selected. Moreover, it is much more favourable if maximum turbocharger speed is the limiting factor rather than a surge limit of the compressor. If this is the case, higher compressor pressure ratios could be achieved resulting in higher engine power output, whereas control of safety device might use only TC speed or related PR across the compressor as an input signal.

Based on the above findings, it is relatively straightforward to select the air management components of the turbocharged diesel engine. Compressor mass flow range should match mass flowrates required by the engine at all operating altitudes. Moreover, in this mass flow range, high maximum pressure ratios of the compressor are required to achieve high PtVR values of the engine. Adequate compressor should also feature high efficiency in this operating range. A suitable intercooler should feature sufficiently high efficiency (equation (3)) to prevent compressor surge at any operating conditions of the engine (more details given in reference [17]). Selection of adequate turbine is slightly more demanding task, since it is not possible to point out such clear directives as for previous components. Based on the extensive research performed on the analysed engine, it turned out that turbine matched for maximum power output at the sea level represents a good initial choice to comply with the requirement specifications listed in section 2. Adequate turbine should enable attaining very high pressure ratios across the turbine before turbine chocking occurs and it should thus also feature high turbine efficiency in that operating range to ensure high PtVRs at high altitudes (equation (5)). If the turbine with adequate corrected mass flowrate characteristic is not available in the production range, it is reasonable to select the next bigger trim, since it suppresses the tendency of turbocharger over-speeding more effectively.

In order to ensure safety operation of the engine, it is also necessary to carefully investigate other engine components that might limit power output at high altitudes and, if necessary, adequately adjust control devices of air management components. In the analysed case, it turned out that controlling maximum turbocharger speed is sufficient, since mechanical and thermal loadings do not limit power output of the engine at any altitude.

sec.title: 6 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p: Results referring to the simulation study of the proposed air management strategy for the turbocharged diesel aircraft engines are presented in this section. Results refer to the engine specified in Table 1 equipped with a single single-stage turbocharger and intercooler. Air management components, i.e. compressor, turbine, and intercooler, were selected upon criteria outlined in the previous section. The characteristics of compressor, turbine, and intercooler applied in the simulation model correspond to characteristics of the series production components.

Results refer to the fully closed waste-gate in all operating conditions, since maximum operating altitude of the engine is attained before maximum turbocharger speed is reached. In the performed feasibility study, it is proposed that turbocharger speed is measured continuously as an additional safety measure to prevent over-speeding of the turbocharger in potential severe off-design operation of the engine. If such situation would occur, waste-gate is opened to prevent over-speeding of the turbocharger; however, in this case, waste-gate acts as an additional safety device and not as a part of the control strategy.

sec.title: 6.1 Analysis of engine performance
sec.p:
Table 2 shows engine parameters for all engine operating points that were defined in the requirement specification and listed in section 2. Additionally, m·C,corr=m·CTb,C/pb,C, nTC,corr=nTC/Tb,C, and PRC values are plotted into the compressor map for all specified operating points (Fig. 7). Figure 7 thus illustrates interaction of the engine with air management components. Compressor map is chosen for interpretation, since operating region of the compressor represents the most severe limitation for stable operation of the engine. It is discernable from Fig. 7 that all operating points corresponding to maximum power outputs at particular altitudes provide ample margins towards unstable or unsafe compressor operation, i.e. surge limit, choke limit, and maximum turbocharger speed. The later fact ensures safe and durable operation of the engine for maximum continuous power output at 3000 and 6000 m. Fig. 7
Compressor performance characteristic with indicated operating points defined in section 2

It is discernable from equation (2) and Table 2 that power output of the engine is proportional to m·C, which is at a certain engine speed proportional to ρIM and further to pa,C (equation (4)) and PRC. Table 2 shows that variation of PRC and pa,C over the flight altitude is in-line with the air management strategy guidelines for turbocharged diesel aircraft engines outlined in Fig. 6. Values of pa,C confirm that proposed turbocharging strategy of diesel aircraft engines enables increasing engine power at all altitudes including very high altitudes above the power output of the corresponding naturally aspired engine. Values of ρIM/ρatm indicate that proposed air management strategy enables significant increase in charge density compared to the ambient one, which proves efficiency of the proposed air management strategy throughout the complete altitude range. Values of BMEP at 3000 r/min are higher than BMEP values corresponding to the maximum power output of the gasoline-turbocharged engines at the sea level, as discussed in subsection 5.2, whereas at 6000 m, engine still attains BMEP of 1 MPa. Moreover, values of PRC and BMEP confirm that proposed turbocharging strategy enables taking full advantage of the enthalpy potential of exhaust gasses at low altitudes resulting in superior BMEP values in general aviation. It is also worth noting that the values of relative air/fuel ratio are relatively high for all operating regimes ensuring moderate thermal loadings and low emissions of black smoke.

Analysing BSFC in Table 2 can be concluded that BSFC is approximately 250 g/kW/h (effective efficiency ηeff = 33.7 per cent) at maximum take-off power at the sea level, being very favourable value for the engine with Vc = 0.53 dm3 at ne = 4200 r/min. BSFC decreases with decreasing engines speed and reaches 229 g/kW/h (ηeff = 36.8 per cent) at full load and 3800 r/min (Table 2), whereas BSFC further decreases with decreasing engine speed featuring less than 220 g/kW/h (ηeff = 38.3 per cent) at full load and 3400 r/min at the sea level. These values indicate high effective efficiency of the engine and therefore confirm efficient matching of air management components to the engine. For comparison, turbocharged gasoline engine [5] features ηeff approximately 28.5 per cent at maximum power. There are no public data from the engine manufacturer available for the fuel consumption of turbocharged gasoline engines [3, 4]. From other publically available sources, it can be estimated that ηeff of those engines attains 28–29 per cent at part load, i.e. at 65 per cent or 75 per cent of the full load.

It can also be concluded that engine features very favourable BSFC values for both engine speeds and full load at 3000 m altitude (Table 2). Efficient air management strategy thus enables attaining very high values of BMEP and PtVRs as well as favourable BSFC at 3000 m. It is discernable from Table 2 that BSFC increases at 6000 m, which is mainly the consequence of lower mechanical efficiency. The later is related to the lower power output of the engine at 6000 m, since indicated power decreases at much higher rate than power of mechanical losses resulting in lower mechanical efficiency. However, values of BSFC between 240 and 260 g/kW/h at 6000 m altitude assure highly fuel-efficient flights due to low atmospheric density and therefore low aerodynamic drag.

Besides very important reduction of operating costs compared to spark ignition-powered aircrafts, higher fuel economy of diesel engines also reduces fuel weight for the same operating range of the aircraft. This fact enables maintaining take-off weight of the aircraft with the analysed engine at the comparable level to the take-off weight of the aircrafts with the highest PtWR spark ignition-turbocharged aircraft engines and the same maximum engine power if long operating range of the aircraft is concerned. Aircrafts featuring long operating range that utilize engines in the power output range of the analysed engine typically feature fuel tank capacities from approximately 230 to 460 L [25]. Improved fuel economy of the analysed engine can thus reduce take-off fuel mass by approximately 30 to 80 kg depending on the fuel tank capacity and efficiency of the comparative spark ignition engine. It is thus discernable that for aircrafts with large fuel tanks, the take-off weight of the aircraft with the analysed engine is comparable to the take-off weight of the aircraft with the highest PtWR spark ignition-turbocharged aircraft engines at equal operating range.

sec.title: 6.2 Concerns related to maximum turbocharger/compressor speed
sec.p: It was indicated above that representation of turbomachinery performance by non-dimensional groups of parameters ensures unique representation independent of the inlet conditions. Based on the Mach number effects, it can be concluded that surge and choke limit given in the corrected values derived from the non-dimensional groups of parameters represent absolute limits for the compressor operating range for variable inlet conditions. However, this is not necessarily applicable to the maximum corrected turbocharger speed (nTC,corr) derived from non-dimensional groups of parameters. Maximum turbocharger speed is generally limited by mechanical stresses and by vibrations of the impeller blades, and it is therefore rather limited by nTC and not by nTC,corr. If this is the case, maximum nTC,corr could be increased by a factor Tref / Tb,C to retain equal nTC for Tb,C<Tref. Shift due to Tref / Tb,C could exceed 10 per cent at high altitudes. For the applied compressor, Tref = 288 K and thus nTC,corr = 137.5 r/s/sqrt(K) corresponds to nTC = 2333 r/s (=140 000 r/min) at reference conditions. The difference between the values of nTC and nTC,corr as well as nTC@288 K = nTC,corrTref=nTCTref / Tb,C is discernable from Table 2. It can be concluded that nTC does not increase with increasing altitude despite increasing nTC,corr. The values of nTC in Table 2 additionally confirm ample margin towards maximum nTC = 2333 r/s and thus ensure safe and durable operation of the turbocharger.

If turbocharger speed (nTC) is measured and it represents the parameter for preventing the turbocharger from over-speeding, a special care should be devoted when operating compressor near maximum nTC at very low ambient temperatures, since values of PRC could exceed maximum value of PRC at reference conditions resulting in higher Mach numbers, which could lead to changed vibration modes of the impeller disc and blades. Approval of the manufacturer is therefore mandatory before exceeding maximum nTC,corr at low ambient temperatures.

sec.title: 6.3 Potential performance improvements
sec.p: The scope of the performed research work and thus of the presented analysis was directed to the air management strategy of turbocharged diesel aircraft engine. In-cylinder phenomena were therefore not investigated and baseline fuel injection equipment and its setting were not changed during the research. From the results in Table 2 that are based on the theoretical study, it is clearly discernable that the analysed engine equipped with selected air management components complies with requirement specifications, whereas results also indicate potential performance improvements. With the existing hardware, it would be possible to further increase power output of the engine by advancing SOI and/or by increasing cyclic fuel delivery, which is made possible by an ample margin towards maximum in-cylinder pressure and by relatively high values of relative air/fuel ratios. At the sea level, a compromise needs to be found between the two increases considering maximum in-cylinder pressure, whereas at higher altitudes, advantage could be taken of both increases. Advancing SOI is particularly favourable at 6000 m, where engine with current settings operates with high relative air/fuel ratios (Table 2), since advancing SOI increases effective efficiency of the engine andthereby decreases enthalpy of exhaust gasses and thus decreases turbocharger speed as well. Simulations were performed using the same rate-of-heat-release curves as for the baseline engine to assess potentials of these parameters. The rate-of-heat-release curves were shifted to mimic variation of SOI, whereas larger cyclic fuel delivery was modelled by increasing the rate of heat released. Although the applied approach is approximative to a certain extend, it could be presumed that applying proposed turbocharging strategy to the analysed engine possesses the potential to reach PtVR above 70 kW/dm3 at the sea level and power output of more than 120 kW at 6000 m with nTC,corr<nTC,corr,max and λset > 1.3. Moreover, optimized engine together with other available compressor trims featuring maximum PRs higher than 4.5 could attain convenient engine parameters also at altitudes beyond 6000 m.

sec.title: 7 CONCLUSION
sec.p: It was shown in this article that innovative air management strategy was successfully applied to a turbocharged diesel aircraft engine. Operating the turbocharged diesel aircraft engines with closed waste-gate up to the critical altitude makes possible to attain superior BMEP values resulting in very high power-to-engine displacement ratios. It was shown that proposed air management strategy is not only capable of compensating for lean operation of the diesel engine but it also enables attaining much higher BMEP values compared to turbocharged gasoline engines especially at lower altitude operation. However, boost pressure decreases towards the critical altitude when applying the proposed air management strategy resulting in proportional reduction of the engine power if air–fuel ratio is maintained at approximately constant value. If maximum operating altitude of the engine is attained before maximum turbocharger speed is reached, the proposed control strategy enables very simple and reliable engine controlling, since waste-gate acts only as an additional safety device and not as a part of the control strategy. However, care should be devoted when selecting air management components, since adequate matching of engine, intercooler, and turbocharger is crucial for taking the full advantage of the proposed air management strategy. Improved engine performance up to the critical altitude resulting from the application of the proposed air management strategy does not lead in performance penalty above the critical altitude, if such operating region could not be avoided, since it is still possible to control the engine by opening the waste-gate above the critical altitude if required.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: The authors acknowledge the financial support of Austro Engine GmbH.
